summary: This document is a compilation of news articles from August 23, 2019, covering the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. It details the expanding criminal investigation into his death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, the opening of a French inquiry into his activities, the legal complexities for his accusers regarding his estate, and Attorney General William Barr's personal involvement in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure who died by suicide in his jail cell on August 10, 2019, while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges. His death triggered multiple investigations.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.context: Oversees the Justice Department and the Bureau of Prisons. He is personally managing the investigations into Epstein's death, has criticized prison irregularities, and has reassigned top officials.

persons.name: Eric Young
persons.role: President of the union representing federal prison workers
persons.context: Disputed Barr's claim that jail employees were uncooperative, stating the Justice Department was unwilling to grant immunity to workers.

persons.name: Hugh Hurwitz
persons.role: Acting Director of the Bureau of Prisons
persons.context: Was reassigned following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.role: Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center
persons.context: Was transferred to an office in Philadelphia following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Remy Heitz
persons.context: Opened a preliminary inquiry into whether Epstein committed sex crimes on French territory or against French minors.

persons.name: Marlene Schiappa
persons.context: Had called on French authorities to open an investigation into Epstein.

persons.name: Nicole Hong
persons.context: Author of an article about the legal morass for Epstein's accusers following his death.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.role: Lawyer representing one of Epstein's accusers
persons.context: Commented on the need for federal courts to ensure victims are not left in limbo while Epstein's associates profit.

persons.name: Kenneth Feinberg
persons.context: Discussed the possibility and mechanics of establishing a compensation fund for Epstein's accusers.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Identified as Jeffrey Epstein's closest relative in the context of his will and estate.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Estate executor, longtime associate of Epstein
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's will, responsible for locating and distributing his assets. Had hired a criminal-defense lawyer.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Estate executor, longtime associate of Epstein
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's will, responsible for locating and distributing his assets. Had hired a criminal-defense lawyer.

persons.name: Katie Benner
persons.context: Author of an article detailing Attorney General William Barr's personal involvement in the Epstein case aftermath.

persons.name: Paul T. Cappuccio
persons.context: Defended Barr's handling of the Epstein case, stating his skill is to doggedly get to the bottom of facts.

persons.name: Christopher Hunter
persons.role: Former FBI agent and prosecutor, Atlantic Council fellow
persons.context: Commented on the erosion of public confidence in federal investigations and the spread of conspiracy theories.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former Labor Secretary, former U.S. Attorney in Miami
persons.context: Resigned as Labor Secretary in July 2019 due to his role in brokering the 2008 non-prosecution agreement for Epstein.

persons.name: David Laufman
persons.context: Questioned whether sufficient oversight from Justice Department leadership was applied to ensure the Bureau of Prisons met its responsibilities for Epstein.

persons.name: Kathleen Hawk Sawyer
persons.role: New permanent director of the Bureau of Prisons
persons.context: Was asked by Barr to return to run the Bureau of Prisons. She was impressed by Barr's detailed knowledge of the Epstein case and prison conditions.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Epstein once socialized with and as a figure who amplified conspiracy theories after Epstein's death. His administration's hiring freeze impacted prison staffing.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Epstein once socialized with, contributing to conspiracy theories surrounding Epstein's death.

connections.description: Barr, as Attorney General, is personally overseeing multiple federal investigations into Epstein's death and the failures at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
Indyke is a longtime associate named as an executor of Epstein's will, responsible for managing his estate.
Kahn is a longtime associate named as an executor of Epstein's will, responsible for managing his estate.
Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and closest relative in the context of his estate.
Young, as union president, publicly disputed Barr's claim that jail employees were uncooperative in the Epstein death investigation.
Barr asked Sawyer to return as director of the Bureau of Prisons. She agreed, believing she would have his support to address the Epstein case and systemic issues.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney in Miami, brokered the 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges and avoid federal prosecution.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan. The New York City medical examiner ruled it a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Epstein's prior suicide attempt
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his cell in a possible suicide attempt, after which he was placed on suicide watch. He was later removed from that watch.

events.title: Epstein's arrest at Teterboro
events.description: Epstein was arrested by FBI agents and NYPD detectives at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey after his private jet landed from Paris. He was charged with federal sex trafficking.

events.title: French prosecutor opens inquiry
events.description: The chief prosecutor in Paris, Remy Heitz, opened a preliminary inquiry to determine if Epstein committed sex crimes on French territory or against French minors.

events.title: Epstein's Florida plea deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to Florida state charges of unlawfully paying a teenage girl for sex. He served 13 months in a county jail under a widely criticized non-prosecution agreement that shielded him from federal charges.

events.title: Epstein signs his will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed his will two days before his death, directing his assets into a trust and naming Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn as executors.

keyFacts: Roughly 15 employees at the Metropolitan Correctional Center were subpoenaed as part of the criminal investigation into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's suicide.

Two staff members in the special housing unit (9 South) are accused of falsifying logs to show they checked on Epstein every 30 minutes when he had not been checked on for about three hours before his death.
Epstein's estate was valued at least $577 million, and his will, signed two days before his death, placed assets in a trust with beneficiaries not publicly disclosed.
Attorney General William Barr personally oversees four federal inquiries into Epstein's death and has taken direct action, including reassigning the Bureau of Prisons director and the MCC warden.
A French preliminary investigation was opened to determine if Epstein committed sex crimes in France, focusing on allegations involving girls aged 15 and older.
